repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
`vim.lsp.completion` behaves poorly with the default 'completeopt'.

Solution:
Set `completeopt+=menuone,noselect` by default. This has a small cost for the builtin CTRL-N completion, which is offset by a big cost-reduction for `vim.lsp.completion`.

Fix #30644

Todo:

- [ ] add `menuone`

comment_regular_data.body:
> How about cmdwin completion?

Do you mean we should `:setlocal completeopt-=noselect` in cmdwin, so that `:s<tab>` selects an item in cmdwin?

> BTW, this may lead to a lot of test conflicts with #30189 :(

`popupmenu_spec.lua` specifically? I can wait until after that PR.

If the cmdwin change is a blocker, then this PR will take some thought. Runtime files currently don't have any special handling (or ftplugin) for `getcmdwintype()` nor `CmdwinEnter`, AFAICT.

I break out the "cleanup" changes from this PR to a separate PR. https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/32915
Also, without `menuone`, does this really solve the problem?

Could it instead be conditionally set on LspAttach event, like is done for mappings like gd and grn?Having to press `<C-p>` twice when not using an Lsp with the autocompletion feature would be a big break from default behaviour.

> Having to press <C-p> twice when not using an Lsp with the autocompletion feature would be a big break from default behaviour.

So maybe it should defaults to "noinsert" instead of "noselect"?

> So maybe it should defaults to "noinsert" instead of "noselect"?

Does that work well for you with `vim.lsp.completion` ? AFAIR it did not.

> Does that work well for you with vim.lsp.completion ? AFAIR it did not.

Can you please tell me why not? My only complain in #30644 is that autocompletion aggressively insert text whenever popup menu just appears, so of course `noinsert` should be just enough to solve it.

Of course this still has a downside, users have to press `Ctrl-y` or `Enter` to accept completion, but at least I think `Enter` is easier to type than any of `Ctrl-p`, `Ctrl-n` as well as any arrow key

> Of course this still has a downside, users have to press `Ctrl-y` or `Enter` to accept completion,

`Enter` doesn't actually accept a completion-item OOTB. Maybe it should.

I'll revisit "noinsert" when I get around to this PR.

I agree that the current defaults are not the best, at least for experience with LSP. For example (luals + Nvim + autotrigger), with the current defaults (`menu,popup`) typing `vim.` results with inserting `F`, so the user have to remove it (e.g. `<Ctrl-e>`) before continue typing with something else f.e. `api`. 

Adding `noselect` prevents from such unwanted insertion of the first result, but (as opposed to `noinsert` and mentioned above) requires to jump to it (`<C-n>`) before confirm.

`preinsert` could be worth discussion here but it cannot be used with `fuzzy` (I haven't checked why).
Now I think the problem is that Nvim is using the same `'completeopt'` for both manual and autocompletion, and there is hardly anyway to satisfy both
Improving built-in completion reveals apparently too broad scope not only for this option (https://github.com/vim/vim/pull/16716).

labels.description: Nvim defaults for options, colorscheme/theme, autocmds/events, etc.
labels.name: defaults

title: feat(defaults): completeopt+=menuone,noselect
